Fig. 1 a) Normalized selectivity (%) and b) CO conversion (%) for MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts tested for CO hydrogenation at 240 °C, 1.0-1.3 bar and a mixture of CO and H2 of 2 mL/min and 4 mL/min, respectively. C2+HC: sum of ethane, ethylene, propane and butane. C2+Oxy: sum of ethanol, acetaldehyde and methyl acetate. Methanol production was only observed for Rh/Fe2O3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 in situ Rh K-edge XAS data of a) 11MnRh under different conditions and b) MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under reaction conditions. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 a) Mn K-edge XAS spectra of 11MnRh taken under different conditions along with MnO2, MnO and Mn-metal (metal foil) standards. b) Mn K-edge XAS spectra of MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under reaction conditions along with an MnO standard. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patters of MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts collected under hydrogen reduction conditions. Dotter lines correspond to the reflections of the different phases determined via Rietveld refinement. Red: iron metal; blue: FeRh alloy phases; yellow: Fe1-xMnxO and Fe3-xMnxO4; black: Fe3O4 and green: MnO. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Phase weight fractions of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under hydrogen reduction conditions. Blue: iron metal; purple: FeRh alloy phases; yellow: Fe3-xMnxO4 and Mn1-xFe1-xO; black: Fe2O3 + Fe3O4; green: MnO. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of MnRh/Fe2O3 under CO hydrogenation conditions along with the main reflections of the phases determined via Rietveld refinement. Red: iron metal; blue: FeRh alloy phases; yellow: Fe1-xMnxO and Fe3-xMnxO4; black: Fe2O3 + Fe3O4;green: MnO and brown: ε′-Fe2.2C and χ-Fe2C5. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Weight fractions of phases determined via Rietveld refinement of MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under CO hydrogenation conditions. Black: iron metal; blue: FeRh alloy phases; yellow: Fe3-xMnxO4 and Mn1-xFe1-xO; purple: Fe2O3+Fe3O4; green: MnO; dark red: ε′-Fe2.2C + χ-Fe2C5. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The k3-weighed Rh K-edge curve model fitting and spectra of the MnRh/Fe2O3 under CO hydrogenation conditions (top three panels) and the scattering paths obtained from the crystal structures used for the modeling (bottom panel). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Product selectivity (left) and phase weight fractions extracted from Rietveld refinements (right) versus Mn:Rh molar ratio for MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts studied under CO hydrogenation conditions after hydrogen reduction. Graphical abstract In situ x-ray diffraction (XRD) and absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to characterize the structure and phase composition of a novel Mn and Fe double-promoted Rh-based catalyst for CO hydrogenation to oxygenates. Catalysts with different Mn:Rh molar ratios were prepared by combining Mn and Rh precursors with Fe2O3 powder, which were then calcined in air and reduced under hydrogen. The resulting MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts are found to be highly selective for ethanol synthesis (∼40 %) for CO hydrogenation under mild conditions (∼1 bar, 240 °C). Comparison of the reactivity results with quantitative phase information from in situ XRD measurements suggest that reduced metal oxides, MnO and FeOx, and metallic Rh co-exist as active phases to promote oxygenate selectivity. The results of this work also highlight the importance of in situ characterization for extracting meaningful information on the active phases of such complex, ternary catalysts which can vary under reaction conditions. Abbreviations Syngas synthetic gas SI supporting information XRD X-ray diffraction XAS X-ray absorbance spectroscopy FT Fourier transform ICP-MS inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy UHP ultra-high purity GHSV gas space hourly velocity GC gas chromatograph TCD thermal conductivity detector CN coordination number EXAFS extended x-ray absorbance fine structure Keywords In situ characterization CO hydrogenation Oxygenate synthesis Rhodium 1 Introduction A major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions comes from the use of petroleum-based transportation fuels that irreversibly convert fossil-energy resources to CO2. Potentially carbon-neutral sources of liquid fuels include bio-ethanol, methanol from CO2 hydrogenation or higher alcohol synthesis (HAS) from biomass-derived syngas (CO2/CO/H2) [1–5]. Among the many types of catalysts tested for HAS from syngas, Rh-based catalysts are some of the best in terms of C2+ oxygenate formation [2,3], but still suffer from low selectivity and poor CO conversion that make them generally unsuitable for industrial scale-up [4]. Improving the performance of Rh-based catalysts typically involves the addition of metal promoters which enhance C2+ oxygenate selectivity by altering the reaction pathways (energetics, kinetics) of CO hydrogenation to favor oxygenate formation [2–5]. Among the metal promoters, iron [6–16] and manganese [13,17–28] have proven to be effective at shifting the product distribution of Rh surfaces from hydrocarbons to oxygenates. HAS formation on Rh surfaces is a complex process that requires CO to be adsorbed dissociatively and molecularly on sites that are in close vicinity [4]. The dissociated CO is hydrogenated to form methyl species, CHx, which can undergo CO insertion to form acyl species (CH3CO), and ultimately ethanol after further hydrogenation [29]. The CO insertion step has a high-energy barrier and is the most important in determining oxygenate selectivity. By comparison, methyl species are readily hydrogenated on the Rh surface to form the more thermodynamically stable product, methane [30,31]. Hence, improving oxygenate selectivity involves increasing the rate of oxygenate formation, e.g., by lowering the barrier for CO insertion, and inhibiting the reaction steps leading to methane (or other hydrocarbons). As a promoter, Fe added to supported Rh catalysts increases oxygenate selectivity by suppressing methane formation, but can also lead to a decrease in CO conversion to products [6,7]. The increases in oxygenate selectivity have been mainly attributed to the presence of FeRh alloy phases [6,16,32–34] that limits Rh atom ensemble sizes and lowers the probability for CO dissociation and, hence, the amount of CH4 produced [34–36]. Mn-modified Rh catalysts have been found to have better oxygenate selectivity and activity (e.g. CO conversion) compared to their unpromoted counterparts [19,22,23,25,28]. The mechanism by which Mn improves HAS selectivity has been attributed to several effects that can be summarized as follows: a) alteration of the local electronic structure of Rh and stabilization of Rh+ species [20,28,37–39]; b) increase of Rh dispersion [17]; 3) Mn-Rh mixed oxide or alloy formation [7,20,26,40] and 4) formation of Rh-MnO interfacial sites [22,28,41]. These modifications of the electronic environment and structure have been attributed to the creation of new active sites for CO insertion [28] and facilitation of CO dissociation via the formation of tilted CO species [27,35,42,43] Theoretical studies have found that Mn doping of Rh surfaces facilitates CO insertion into methyl species by lowering the energy barrier for this step [7,44]. The differences in the mechanisms of how Fe and Mn favor oxygenate formation on Rh surfaces can be seen as complimentary. Thus, they have been combined as Mn-Fe-Rh-catalysts supported on silica [33,45–49], alumina [50,51] and titania [52]. These double-promoted catalysts exhibit superior oxygenate selectivity compared to their single-metal promoted counterparts. Very recent experimental studies of MnFeRh/SiO2 catalysts indicate the formation of FeRh alloys and a catalyst morphology in which Rh/FeRh nanoparticles are partially covered by (Mn,Fe)Ox (x<0.25) mixed oxides [46,49]. Oxygenate formation was also attributed to the presence of Mn-Fe mixed oxides and their interface with Rh [46]. In general, the double-promoted Mn-Fe-Rh catalysts are structurally very complex and much remains to be learned about the electronic environments, phases and local atomic structures of the Rh, Fe and Mn components. In this work we used a combination of reactivity testing and in situ x-ray characterization to study the structure and phase composition of a novel Mn and Fe double-promoted Rh-based catalyst for CO hydrogenation to oxygenates. The goal was to identify the active phases of the Mn, Fe and Rh components that are responsible for oxygenate formation. Catalyst design is based on our previous study where we used in situ preparation of FeRh alloys via reduction of a Rh/nano-Fe2O3 catalyst [16]. The FeRh alloy content correlated with increases in oxygenate selectivity, but also with decreased CO conversion. In this work, Mn is added to the Rh/Fe2O3 catalysts to further improve oxygenate selectivity; the Fe2O3 support again serves both as metal oxide support and Fe source. Under CO hydrogenation conditions, the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts exhibit higher oxygenate selectivity than Rh/Fe2O3 with no changes in CO conversion for Mn loading as high as 20 wt%. In situ characterization using x-ray diffraction (XRD) and x-ray absorption (XAS) under hydrogen reduction and CO hydrogenation conditions were performed to elucidate the oxidation states, chemical phases and local atomic structures of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts. Comparisons of reactivity results with quantitative phase information derived from in situ XRD measurements indicate that MnO and FeOx oxides and their interfaces with metallic Rh (including FeRh alloy) are the active phases that promote oxygenate selectivity on MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts. Overall, this work presents a novel approach for preparing double-promoted Rh catalysts and, to our knowledge, the first in situ study of the structure and phase composition of these systems under reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The MnRh/Fe2O3 powder catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation. For this, Mn and Rh nitrates (Mn(NO3)2xH2O; Rh(NO3)2xH2O, Sigma-Aldrich ©) were dissolved in deionized water until a solution was formed. The amount of Rh was fixed at 2% wt., while the Mn content was varied between 4–24 % wt. The 2% Rh loading used here represents a balance between sufficient baseline activity for oxygenate formation [6,16], while also minimizing precious metal use which is a potential drawback of Rh-based catalysts. The solution was added in a drop-wise fashion to weighed nanosized Fe2O3 powders (Sigma-Aldrich ©) that resulted in a paste. The paste was dried overnight at 120C, and then calcined at 450C for four hours. The calcination product was grinded using a mortar and pestle producing a powdered sample. The samples are referred as 5MnRh, 7MnRh, 11MnRh, 18MnRh and 22MnRh, where the integers correspond to the manganese to rhodium molar ratio. The Mn loading and Mn to Rh molar ratio was confirmed via inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) measurements performed at the Spectroscopy and Biophysics Core of the University of Nebraska (Table S1). As for the non-containing Mn sample, this will be indicated as Rh/Fe2O3 in the manuscript and as Rh in the figures, and the bare support is noted as Fe2O3. For comparison purposes, catalytic tests were also performed on MnRh/TiO2 catalysts with 2 wt. % Rh and various loadings of Mn. The synthesis of the MnRh/TiO2 catalysts is described in Supporting Information (SI), Section 2. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurements Catalytic performance studies were carried out to determine the catalytic activity and carbon selectivity resulting from CO hydrogenation to molecular products. Approximately 40 mg of the catalysts were loaded into 1/8” OD glass capillaries using glass wool as plugs. The capillary loaded with the sample was placed in a flow-plug reactor based on the design of Chupas et al. [53] This type of reactor was used to allow direct comparisons with in situ data obtained at the various synchrotron facilities that required the use of capillary reactors of similar dimensions. The catalysts were heated via a filament around the capillary connected to a DC power supply. Temperature was monitored with a thermocouple inserted inside the capillary. The CO and H2 gases used were UHP grade and controlled by a mass flow controller (MKS Inst.). The gas hourly space velocity (GSHV) reported hereafter and in the Supplementary Information were calculated based on the capillary dimensions. The samples were reduced under 9 mL/min of H2 at 1.0–1.3 bar (GHSV=1680 h−1) for 30 min at 300C. After reduction, the heating was turned off and when the sample reached room temperature (RT), the gas flow was set to gas mixture of CO and H2 at 2 mL/min and 4 mL/min, respectively for 30 min. The CO hydrogenation catalytic measurements were performed at a pressure of 1.0–1.3 bar (GHSV = 1140 h−1), and a temperature of 240 °C. This temperature was determined in a previous study to give the best activity and selectivity for oxygenate and ethanol production for CO hydrogenation [6]. The product distribution was analyzed online using a gas chromatograph (GC, an Agilent 3000 Micro GC) that was connected to a stainless-steel tubing to the gas exhaustion laboratory system and the reactor via a heated 1/8” OD. In this type of set up, the gases exiting the reactor are split between the GC inlet and an exhaust line into a hood; although the exhaust line is pressurized above ambient it was nonetheless difficult to make accurate quantification of gases found in the atmosphere like CO2. Amounts of CO2 and water were usually found when pre-reaction conditions were run (RT). The identification and quantification of the products was performed using calibration curves for each compound. The GC is equipped with three micro columns separated in channels, and a TCD detector. Channel A corresponds to an MS-5A PLOT column used to detect carbon monoxide and methane. Channel B has an Agilent PLOT-U column that was used to detect higher hydrocarbons. Channel C was equipped with a Stabilwax column for the identification of oxygenate compounds, e.g., ethanol, acetaldehyde, methyl acetate. Continuous measurements (each ∼6 min) were taken until the steady state was reached, after approximately 2.5 h. The CO conversion (%) and selectivity of product i, Si (%), were calculated on a carbon basis using the expressions below (1) % C O C o n v e r s i o n = ∑ n i ∙ M i M C O ⋅ 100 % (2) S i = n i ∙ M i ∑ n i ∙ M i ⋅ 100 % where ni is the number of carbon atoms in product i, Mi is the percentage of product i detected, and MCO is the percentage of carbon monoxide in the gas feed. 2.3 In situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) In situ x-ray characterization studies using synchrotron radiation were performed to determine the phases present and the local electronic and structural environment of the active metals. In situ x-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected at the 11-ID-B beamline at the Advance Photon Source located at Argonne National Laboratory. XRD patterns were collected at a photon energy of 55.6 keV (0.211 Å). The detector used for the XRD measurements was a Perkin Elmer amorphous silicon 2-D at a distance of 600 mm from the sample. Cerium dioxide was used as standard for calibration. The catalyst samples were loaded into 1.2 mm (OD) Kapton ® capillaries and mounted into a plug-flow reactor provided at the beamline. The total gas flows were modified to match the GSHV used for the catalytic measurements (See Supporting Information, Section 3). Data was collected for the as-synthesized samples under Ar flow at room temperature, after H2 reducing conditions at 300 °C for 30 min, and under CO hydrogenation conditions at 240 °C for one hour. The unpromoted Mn catalyst (Rh/Fe2O3) was also probed under the same conditions. The GSAS-II software package [54] was used to convert the XRD diffraction images into 1-D, 2-theta scans and to analyze the XRD patterns via Rietveld refinement. Crystallographic files obtained from the Pearson’s Crystal Data database were used to model the collected XRD patterns. A more complete description of the Rietveld analyses is given in SI, Section 3. 2.4 In situ X-ray absorbance spectroscopy (XAS) X-ray absorption (XAS) spectra at the Rh and Mn K-edges were collected at the 5-BM-D beamline at the Advance Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory for the as-synthesized catalysts, under hydrogen reducing and CO hydrogenation conditions. The samples were loaded into 2.2 mm (OD) Kapton ® capillaries that were mounted into the same plug-flow reactor used for the in-house activity measurements. The conditions for catalyst reducition were 4.5 mL/min of H2 at a GHSV=1100 h−1at 300 °C, and for CO hydrogenation a mixture of CO (3 mL/min) and H2 (6 mL/min) at GHSV=1100 h−1 and 240 °C was used. In both cases, the data collection was performed after 30 min at the aforementioned conditions. For the in situ XAS measurements under CO hydrogenation conditions, the data acquisition set point was chosen as this was identified during the catalytic activity tests when oxygenate production started. The Rh K-edge and Mn K-edge energies were calibrated using the spectra of the manganese metal and rhodium metal reference foil spectra measured simultaneously with the samples. [23] The edge position was chosen as the first inflection point on the leading absorption peak. This was chosen to be 23,220 eV for the Rh reference foil (Rh K-edge) and 6539 eV for the Mn metal reference foil (Mn K-edge). Fluorescence data was collected using a 13-element germanium multichannel detector. Normalization, energy calibration, background subtraction and curve fit analysis were performed using the Atoms, Athena and Artemis software package that are based on IFFEFIT [55]. See SI, Section 4, for more details about the approaches used for the analysis of the EXAFS data. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activity measurements To determine the catalytic activity and carbon selectivity, the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts were tested under CO hydrogenation conditions at 240 °C, a pressure of 1.0–1.3 bar and a gas mixture of H2/CO of 2:1. Prior to reactivity testing, the catalysts were reduced at 300 °C under hydrogen flow. The normalized product selectivity and CO conversion are shown in Fig. 1 a and b, respectively, and the values for the individual products are shown in Table 1 . As it can be seen in Fig. 1a, addition of Mn to Rh/Fe2O3 increases the C2+ oxygenate selectivity whereas the C2+ hydrocarbon selectivity decreases. The oxygenate selectivity rises to a maximum of about 55 % (Table 1) at a Mn:Rh molar ratio of ∼11 and then varies only slightly at higher Mn loadings. The main oxygenates are ethanol (∼40 %) followed by acetaldehyde (∼10 %) and methyl acetate (∼2%). The improvements in oxygenate selectivity with Mn addition are generally consistent with previous studies of Fe and Mn promoted Rh catalysts [33,47,51,52]. From Fig. 1a and Table 1, it can be seen that the addition of Mn decreases the selectivity for C2+ hydrocarbons to about ∼20 % for Mn:Rh molar ratios ≥ 11 %, mostly due to a drop in propane and butane formation (Table 1). The primary C2+ hydrocarbons for all catalysts are ethane and ethylene, with a selectivity that becomes roughly the same (∼10 %) at higher Mn loadings. As for methane selectivity, the full range of Mn loadings result in a decrease from 37 % to 27 %. The decrease in ethylene and methane selectivity with Mn addition to Rh/Fe2O3 has been previously reported on Mn-promoted FeOx Fischer Tropsch catalysts [56–59]. This suggests that Mn may not only be modifying the Rh surface, but also interacts with the Fe2O3 support. The results of catalytic tests for MnRh/TiO2 catalysts for Mn loadings from 1−8 wt. % (∼2 wt. % Rh) are summarized in SI, Table S2. Titania was chosen for comparison as Rh/TiO2 is active for CO hydrogenation [60], and TiO2 is a reducible oxide like Fe2O3. As seen in Table S2, the addition of Mn to Rh/TiO2 leads to similar increases in oxygenate selectivity and hydrocarbon suppression, albeit with lower CO conversion and significantly higher methane yields. Nonetheless, Mn is playing the same role in enhancing the selectivity for ethanol synthesis by suppressing hydrocarbon formation for both Rh/Fe2O3 and Rh/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 1b and Table 1 show that the CO conversion values are largely unaffected by increases in Mn loading, with an average value of ∼2.4 %. The ability of Mn addition to improve oxygenate selectivity and increase CO conversion has been found for some single Mn-promoted Rh catalysts [19,22,24,28]. However, analogous effects to our MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts have been recently reported for other MnFeRh catalysts [33,49,50,52], and increases in both CO conversion and oxygenate selectivity have been found in other MnFe-promoted Rh catalysts supported on alumina (a comparison of CO conversion and product selectivity for Mn and Fe promoted Rh catalysts on different supports is given in Table S3) [51]. By contrast, the addition of Fe [6] or Mn (Table S2) to Rh/TiO2 catalysts results in a significant drop in CO conversion. In this respect, the near constant CO conversion with Mn addition (Fig. 1b), along with lower methane selectivity (Table 1 and S2), suggests that Fe2O3 is superior to TiO2 as a support. In the absence of Mn, this has been attributed to the in situ formation of FeRh alloys on Rh/Fe2O3 under reaction conditions [6,8,10,16]. To understand how Mn addition to the Rh/Fe2O3 system affects the distribution of metallic and oxide phases present during reaction conditions, we performed detailed in situ x-ray characterization measurements, the results of which are described below. 3.2 Oxidation states from in situ XAS The oxidation states of Rh and Mn in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts were probed via in situ XAS under different reaction conditions. Fig. 2 a shows the XAS spectra of the as-synthesized 11MnRh catalyst, under H2 reduction and CO hydrogenation conditions. Comparing the edge position and the white line intensity with the Rh standards, the spectrum closely matches that of Rh2O3, i.e., Rh in the as-prepared catalyst is present as Rh2O3. During H2 reduction, the 11MnRh sample exhibits a decrease in the white line intensity as well a shift to lower energy (22,320 eV) that is similar to the Rh metal standard indicating a reduction of the Rh oxide phase to metallic Rh. There is no further change in either the white line intensity or edge position under CO hydrogenation conditions. Thus, Rh is metallic under both H2 reduction and CO hydrogenation conditions. The other MnRh/Fe2O3 samples exhibit identical behavior under reduction and reaction conditions (Fig. 2b). The main differences in the Rh K-edge XAS spectra are in the continuum resonances above 23,240 eV, which are weaker in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts compared to the Rh metal foil. A decrease in the continuum resonance intensities has been attributed to a lower Rh coordination as compared to bulk metallic Rh [61]. Fig. 3 a shows the Mn K-edge XAS spectra of the 11MnRh catalyst under different conditions along with spectra of some Mn standards (Mn metal foil, MnO2, and MnO). The spectrum of the as-synthesized 11MnRh catalyst exhibits an edge energy close to that of the MnO2 standard. Under hydrogen reduction conditions, the edge position of 11MnRh shifts to lower energy and is similar to that of the MnO standard and remains unchanged under CO hydrogenation conditions. Similar edge energies and spectral features are observed for the other MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under reaction conditions as shown in Fig. 3b. A quantitative determination of the oxidation state of Mn was performed via the construction of a calibration curve given in Fig. S1 [62]. The calculated values obtained for 7MnRh and 11MnRh are given in Table 2 . For both catalysts, the Mn oxidation states decrease from 3.7 ± 0.1 (as-synthesized) to 2.2 ± 0.1 under reduction and reaction conditions. The pre-edge feature of Mn K-edge (∼6540 eV) XAS is due to 1s→empty 3d level transitions and its position and intensity can be used to assess the local Mn symmetry [63]. For the as-synthesized 11MnRh sample, the intensity and centroid energy of the pre-edge peak (∼6542.5 eV), and the white line shape and intensity closely resemble that of the MnO2 standard. Thus, we speculate that the as-synthesized sample contains an MnO2-like phase. The fact that the derived oxidation state is slightly lower than 4+ expected for MnO2 (Table 2) could be due to atomic mixing of Mn into the Fe2O3 lattice to form a mixed oxide during catalyst preparation. Such mixed Mn-Fe oxides have been previously reported for MnFe Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [64]. Under reaction conditions, the pre-edge energy positions of all the MnRh samples match that of MnO (∼6541 eV; see Fig. 3b), but have higher intensities. The latter has been interpreted as due to Mn2+ cations in highly distorted octahedral sites as compared to crystalline MnO [63]. The lower intensities of the features in the energy range 6550−6560 eV for the MnRh/Fe2O3 samples have also been attributed to MnO of low crystallinity [65]. These spectral features suggest that the Mn in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts is present as MnO with low crystallinity or consists of a mix of MnOx phases [62]. 3.3 Phase analyses from in situ XRD 3.3.1 MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under hydrogen reduction conditions In situ XRD measurements were performed in order to gain more information about the Mn, Fe and Rh phases formed under catalyst activation (hydrogen reduction). Fig. 4 shows a region of the XRD patterns of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts, the unpromoted Rh/Fe2O3 sample and the bare Fe2O3 support. Structural analyses were performed via Rietveld refinement (see SI for details) and the peak assignments are shown at the top of Fig. 4. The results of the phase analyses including cell parameters are given in SI, Table S4. During hydrogen reduction, most of the bare support is converted to Fe3O4 with a small amount of metallic α-Fe (bcc). By comparison, the unpromoted Rh/Fe2O3 catalyst contains only a minor fraction of Fe3O4 and mainly exhibits peaks related to α-Fe. The latter has been attributed to hydrogen spillover from H2 dissociation on Rh surfaces that removes oxygen from the Fe2O3 support via the formation of water [16]. The diffraction peaks of α-Fe exhibit asymmetric tails to lower 2-theta previously attributed to the formation of FeRh alloy phases [16]. Except for 5MnRh, Mn addition to Rh/Fe2O3 results in increased intensity of diffraction peaks related to a Fe3O4 oxide phase. This is better illustrated in Fig. 5 , where the phase fractions extracted from Rietveld refinement are plotted against Mn:Rh molar ratio. As the Mn loading increases, the amount of metallic α-Fe diminishes while the Fe3O4 oxide phase content increases. The inverse relationship between Mn loading and α-Fe content suggests that Mn is limiting the extent of reduction of the Fe2O3 support [16]. Not surprisingly, the FeRh alloy content also decreases at higher Mn loadings, probably as a result of the limited availability of metallic Fe at the Rh/FeOx interfaces. In addition to controlling the levels of reduction of Fe2O3, Mn at higher loading (7MnRh, 11MnRh and 18MnRh) results in the appearance of MnO and Mn-Fe oxide phases (Fig. 4). The peaks associated with MnO exhibit a shoulder to higher 2-theta that can be attributed to lattice contraction of the MnO cell due to dissolution of some Fe (II) and formation of a manganowustite-like phase (Mn1-xFexO) [66]. Such mixed Mn-Fe oxide phases have previously been identified as an intermediate step in the hydrogen reduction of co-precipitated Mn and Fe mixed oxides to metallic Fe and MnO [67,68]. Although FeO has also been suggested to be a product of hydrogen reduction of these Mn and Fe mixed oxides [66], the contraction of the lattice parameter (Table S4) obtained via Rietveld refinement is better matched to that of Mn0.5Fe0.5O than to FeO. The presence of a Fe3-xMnxO4 mixed oxide was also determined via Rietveld refinement at the highest Mn loadings studied (11MnRh and 18MnRh). The Fe3-xMnxO4 is a spinel where Mn is found as Mn3+ occupying octahedral sites [62]. Since it is difficult to determine the exact composition of the Fe-Mn mixed oxides via Rietveld refinement, we refer to them as Fe3-xMnxO4 and Mn1-xFe1-xO. The presence of the Fe-Mn mixed oxides, and MnO would lead to a mix of +2 and +3 Mn oxidation states, in agreement with the average value of +2.2 (Table 2) determined via Mn K-edge XAS measurements (Fig. 3). The presence of the two mixed oxides (Fe3-xMnxO4 and Mn1-xFe1-xO) is likely due to the formation of a MnOx-Fe2O3 interface that allows limited intermixing of the metallic cations. This is consistent with the observation in Fig. 5 that the FeMnOx content increases with increasing Mn loading. As a summary of this section, Mn addition to Rh/Fe2O3 catalysts decreases the amount of Fe2O3 reduced to metallic α-Fe under hydrogen reduction and thereby limits the extent of FeRh alloy formation. This is also clear from Figure S2, where we plot the relative amounts of Rh in the FeRh alloys relative to the total Rh loading under reducing conditions; for the 5Mn:Rh sample, ∼70 % of the Rh is present as FeRh alloys and drops to ∼40 % for the catalysts with higher Mn loadings. Two mixed oxides, Fe3-xMnxO4 and Mn1-xFe1-xO, are identified from Rietveld refinements of the in situ XRD data, which are likely to be produced via close contact of MnOx and Fe2O3 phases. Mixed Mn-Fe oxides were also found to partially cover Rh nanoparticles in a recent TEM study of Mn-Fe/Rh/SiO2 catalysts [49]. The presence of a MnO or Fe-Mn oxide surface layer covering Rh surfaces in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts studied here could limit the reduction of the Fe2O3 support by preventing hydrogen spillover from Rh particles or by sacrificial reduction of Mn oxides to form reduced MnO. 3.3.2 MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts under reaction conditions The XRD patterns for the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts, the unpromoted Rh/Fe2O3 catalyst and the bare Fe2O3 support under CO hydrogenation conditions (after hydrogen reduction) are shown in Fig. 6 . The peak assignments in Fig. 6 were obtained from Rietveld analyses. Unlike the case of H2 reduction, the Rh/Fe2O3 catalyst under CO hydrogenation now shows a large fraction of Fe carbide along a smaller amount of metallic α-Fe [16]. The main carbide phase can be assigned to be ε′-Fe2.2C [69] but also a smaller portion of the Hägg carbide (χ-Fe2C5) can be identified. The amount of residual Fe oxide is only ∼10 % (Table S5). With increasing Mn addition, there is a steady decrease in the diffraction peaks related to the iron carbides, whereas changes in the intensities of peaks related to MnO, the Fe-Mn mixed oxides and Fe3O4 are more difficult to ascertain by visual inspection. The latter were quantitatively assessed via Rietveld refinement and the results of the weight fractions versus the Mn:Rh molar ratio is shown in Fig. 7 . Increases in the MnO and FeMnOx phases are closely related to the decrease in Fe carbide content, which might suggest that the oxide phases inhibit the carburization of the iron oxide support. The inhibition of iron carbide formation with Mn addition has also been observed for Mn promoted iron oxide based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [56,62,70]. The decrease in the iron carbide phase with Mn loading is also correlated with the decrease in α-Fe metal content. This is consistent with metallic α-Fe being the precursor of the carbide phases under CO hydrogenation conditions [16]. As for the FeRh alloy phases, there is a decrease in the reflections associated with the FeRh phases under reaction conditions (Fig. 6) compared to the samples reduced under hydrogen for the same Mn loading (Tables S4 and S5). As shown in Figs. 7 and S3, the FeRh content drops by about 50 % for the 5MnRh and 7MnRh samples relative to the Rh sample and continues to decrease at higher Mn loadings (11MnRh and 18MnRh). Not surprisingly, the FeRh alloy content roughly follows the amount of metallic α-Fe in the sample, which slowly decreases for Mn:Rh ratios ≥ 7 (Fig. 7) and is smaller for all samples under hydrogen reduction. The presence of FeRh alloys have previously been correlated to enhancements in oxygenate selectivity [16] and are present in all the MnRhFe catalysts, albeit at low levels under reaction conditions (Figs. 7 and S3). The relatively large α-Fe content of the 5MnRh sample does not follow a smooth trend with Mn loading, and may be related to the fact that MnO can stabilize metallic Fe at low Mn loadings [67], which is the case of 5MnRh. From the in situ XRD analyses during CO hydrogenation of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts, it is seen that the main effect of Mn addition to Rh/Fe2O3 is to prevent the transformation of the iron oxide support to carbide. The likely origin of the iron carbides is the α-Fe produced under hydrogen reduction conditions as previously suggested for the un-promoted Rh/Fe2O3 catalysts. Consequently, the Fe carbides, metallic α-Fe and FeRh alloy phases decrease under CO hydrogenation conditions with Mn loading. By comparison, the trends in MnO and FeMnOx, and Fe3O4 phase content with Mn loading show little change in going from reducing to reaction conditions. 3.4 Local structure of Rh from in situ XAS extended fine structure (EXAFS) The local atomic structure of Rh was probed via Rh K-edge EXAFS measurements under CO hydrogenation conditions. Fig. 8 shows the magnitude of the k3-weighted Fourier transform (FT) of the Rh K-edge EXAFS for the 5MnRh, 7MnRh and 11MnRh catalysts under reaction conditions. No contributions from Rh-O bonds (radial distance ∼1.6 Å) were found under reducing or reaction conditions, consistent with the Rh K-edge results that showed that Rh is in its metallic state. According to Fig. 8, the first coordination shell of metallic Rh (radial distance between 1.7–2.8 Å) is split into two peaks centered at approximately at ∼2.05 Å and ∼2.45 Å. Based on previous work, the shorter path (∼2.05 Å) is assigned to Fe-Rh bonds of a FeRh alloy [71], whereas the feature at ∼2.45 Å can be attributed to Rh-Rh scattering. The latter assignment is supported by the calculated scattering paths derived from a Rh metal model seen in the bottom panel of Fig. 8. Although a Mn-Rh alloy formation could also produce a contribution at ∼2.05 Å, the existence of a Mn-Rh alloy/intermetallic is highly unlikely based on the Mn K-edge XAS (Fig. 3) and XRD results, as well as the instability of a Mn-Rh alloy at the conditions studied in here (300 °C, reduction, and 240 °C, reaction conditions) [72]. Curve fitting analyses based on structural models were performed for 5MnRh, 7MnRh and 11MnRh under reduction and reaction conditions and the results are summarized in Table 3 . The data was fitted using crystallographic models that represent interactions for Rh-Rh (metal), Rh-Rh (Rh-Fe alloy) and Rh-Fe (Fe-Rh alloy/intermetallic) (See SI, Section 4). The fitted Fe-Rh radial distances for the reduced samples vary from 2.51 to 2.60 Å which are within experimental error of values reported in the literature (2.55 Å [73] and 2.62 Å [74]). The relatively large range of fitted values could be due to the interferences between Fe-Rh and Rh-Rh scattering paths that complicates the analyses [75]. Under CO hydrogenation conditions, the samples exhibit Fe-Rh interatomic distances of ∼2.55 Å [73] similar to that found in our previous studies on Rh supported on Fe2O3 powders [16]. The coordination numbers of Fe-Rh contributions obtained for MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts exhibit lower values (CNRh-Fe = 1.6–2.4, Table 3) compared to those obtained for Rh/Fe2O3 catalyst without Mn (CNRh-Fe = 3.3) [16]. This comparison suggests that Mn addition limits the amount of Fe-Rh interactions. This is consistent with the Rietveld refinement results, which show a decrease in the FeRh phases with increasing Mn addition (Figs. 5 and 7). The EXAFS and XRD results cannot provide information on the homogeneity of FeRh alloys or if these coexist with Rh only nanoparticles on the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts. However, the CNTotal in all the samples under reaction conditions (Table 3) have values are less than 12, which is the CN corresponding to bulk fcc Rh. This indicative of the presence of the Rh ensembles as nanoparticles [76]. 4 Discussion Quantitative structural analyses of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts show that the α-Fe content under reducing conditions (Fig. 5) and the carbide content under CO hydrogenation conditions (Fig. 7) are inversely correlated to the Mn loading. Iron carbide phases can be derived from metallic α-Fe that is carburized during CO hydrogenation conditions [77,78]. The iron oxide support itself is another plausible source of iron carbides [79], however, there is no evident change in the Fe3O4 phase content in going from hydrogen reduction (Fig. 5) to CO hydrogenation conditions (Fig. 7). Therefore, we conclude that Mn is limiting the extent of the carburization of the Fe3O4 support under CO hydrogenation conditions. The decrease in iron carbide content with increasing Mn loading is closely related to the decrease in hydrocarbon selectivity. This correlation is consistent with previous studies which have shown that the ε′-Fe2.2C and χ-Fe2C5 carbide phases are active for hydrocarbon production at temperatures close to the reaction temperature used in here (240 °C) [16,69,80]. As for methane production, we can attribute its production to both iron carbide and metallic Rh phases[30,81]. The presence of FeRh alloys in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts is confirmed via Rh K-edge EXAFS analyses (Fig. 8 and Table 3). As shown in Figs. 5 and 7 (also Tables S4 and S5), the amount of FeRh correlates with the metallic α-Fe content of the catalysts which is larger during hydrogen reduction as compared to CO hydrogenation conditions. In general, accurate quantification of the FeRh alloy phases is challenging due to their small amounts and the possibility of multiple phases. Previous studies propose that FeRh alloy phases are responsible for increases in oxygenate selectivity for Fe-promoted, oxide supported Rh catalysts [6,7,9,12,16,32,33,49], however, the very small FeRh alloy content of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts studied here (Fig. 7 and S3) suggest that they may not be the primary active phase for promoting oxygenate production under reaction conditions. To identify the Mn, Fe and Rh phases responsible for oxygenate formation in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts, reactivity-phase relationships were constructed by combining the results from reactivity studies (Fig. 1a) and the phase fractions present in the catalysts under CO hydrogenation conditions (Fig. 7). As noted above, the FeRh alloy content of the catalysts is quite small under reaction conditions (Fig. 7 and S3) and does not correlate with increases in oxygenate selectivity observed at higher Mn loading. Under these conditions, most of the Rh is present as un-alloyed metallic nanoparticles whose surfaces are partially covered with MnO, FeOx and mixed FeMnOx oxide species [49]. Bare Rh surfaces are likely to contribute to the formation of methane which is present for all Mn loadings. By contrast, trends for the MnO and FeOx phase contents most closely follow the increases in oxygenate selectivity, suggesting that these oxides and/or their interfaces with Rh are responsible for the improved catalytic performance at higher Mn loadings. A recent study of MnFeRh/SiO2 catalysts suggested that the active site for oxygenate formation is a (Fe,Mn)Ox phase or its interface with Rh [46]. As seen in Fig. 9 , the (Fe,Mn)Ox phases increase significantly for Mn loadings > 5 wt. %, but the correlation with oxygenate selectivity is less clear than for MnO and FeOx phase contents over the same range of Mn loadings. Finally, we note that similar improvements in oxygenate selectivity also correlate with the presence of MnO (Fig. S4) in the MnRh/TiO2 catalysts studied here under the same conditions (Table S2). The reactivity-structure relationships presented in this work also suggest the use of Mn-Fe mixed oxides as supports for Rh [64,82,83] as a way of further improving catalytic performance for HA synthesis. Overall, the correlations in Fig. 9 suggest that Mn addition leads to the formation of MnO and FeOx phases, and their intermixing, and these phases have the greatest impact on improving oxygenate selectivity of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts. Moreover, the product distributions and oxygenate selectivity do not change significantly for Mn:Rh molar ratios > 11 (see Table 1), suggesting that the Mn loading is near optimal for the 11MnRh sample. Higher loadings of Mn lead to a somewhat larger fractions of MnO and (MnFe)Ox phases and a concomitant decrease in FeOx content, but no improvements in oxygenate selectivity (see Figs. 7 and 9). Moreover, the FeRh alloy content of the catalysts is quite small for larger Mn loadings, such that ≥ 90 % of the Rh in these catalysts is un-alloyed, metallic Rh (See Figure S3). A plausible explanation for these observations is that all possible interfaces with metallic Rh (and FeRh) species are saturated for the 11MnRh sample and that further addition of Mn simply adds inactive (for oxygenates) oxide components to the catalysts. This further suggests that both MnO and FeOx interfaces with Rh (and FeRh alloy) nanoparticles are responsible for improved oxygenate selectivity. This conclusion is consistent with previous studies of Mn-only promoted Rh catalysts which identified MnO as the active phase for promoting oxygenate formation [17,22,28,41,43] through the presence of Rh-MnO interfacial sites [22,28,41,43]. Likewise, active sites for the ternary FeMnRh/Al2O3 catalyst involve Rh and FeOx interfaces, i.e., (Rhx°–Rhy +)–O–Fe3+(Fe2+) [51], while MnO and FeOx and (Mn, Fe)Ox are active components of FeMnRh/SiO2 catalysts via interfaces with Rh and FeRh alloy [33,49,46]. At present there is no general agreement in the literature how these interfaces influence specific reaction steps in the overall mechanism and much of this information is derived from theoretical studies using DFT and KMC modeling on model systems [7,12,22,26,30,33,40,84]. The roles of FeOx-Rh and MnO-Rh interfaces appear to be similar in that they both block Rh sites, e.g., step edges, that favor methane formation; FeOx-Rh is also found to promote hydrogenation of acetaldehyde to ethanol while MnO-Rh lowers the barrier for CO dissociation and stabilizing intermediates leading to acetaldehyde [22]. Although the MnFeRh ternary systems is structurally more complex, the recent study of Yang, et al., suggested that the MnO and FeOx components act independently and so that the ternary system can be considered as the “sum” of both promoters [12]. 5 Conclusions In this work we employed a novel catalyst design to prepare a ternary Mn-Fe-Rh catalyst in which Mn is added as a promoter and Fe is provided by the reduction of the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalyst under reaction conditions. The resulting MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts work are highly selective for oxygenate synthesis under mild conditions (240 °C and ∼1 bar), where the main oxygenate produced is ethanol (∼40 % selectivity). Correlations of the reactivity data with the results of in situ x-ray characterization (XRD, XAS, EXAFS) measurements suggest that the enhanced oxygenate selectivity in the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts results from the complex interplay between MnO and reduced FeOx oxide phases with metallic Rh which co-exist under CO hydrogenation conditions. Presence of FeRh alloys was also found during reaction conditions, however, their very low content suggests it is not playing a primary role in driving oxygenate formation. Here, the Mn promoter influences the chemical behavior of both the active Rh metal and the Fe2O3 support, so that the MnRh/Fe2O3 catalyst is compositionally very different than the unpromoted Rh/Fe2O3 catalysts under reaction conditions. The results of this work also highlight the importance of in situ characterization for extracting meaningful information on the active phases of such complex, ternary catalysts under reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: In situ x-ray diffraction (XRD) and absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to characterize the structure and phase composition of a novel Mn and Fe double-promoted Rh-based catalyst for CO hydrogenation to oxygenates. Catalysts with different Mn:Rh molar ratios were prepared by combining Mn and Rh precursors with Fe2O3 powder, which were then calcined in air and reduced under hydrogen. The resulting MnRh/Fe2O3 catalysts are found to be highly selective for ethanol synthesis (∼40 %) for CO hydrogenation under mild conditions (∼1 bar, 240 °C). Comparison of the reactivity results with quantitative phase information from in situ XRD measurements suggest that reduced metal oxides, MnO and FeOx, and metallic Rh co-exist as active phases to promote oxygenate selectivity. The results of this work also highlight the importance of in situ characterization for extracting meaningful information on the active phases of such complex, ternary catalysts which can vary under reaction conditions.
coredata.dc:title: In situ structural study of manganese and iron oxide promoted rhodium catalysts for oxygenate synthesis
